Scheduled-Asynchronous Distributed Algorithm
for Optimal Power Flow

Chin-Yao Chang  Jorge Cortés  Sonia Martínez C.-Y. Chang, Jorge Cortés, and Sonia Martínez are with the Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of California, San Diego, CA, USA. Email: {chc433,cortes,soniamd}@ucsd.eduA preliminary version of this work appeared as [1] at the 2017 American Control Conference.
Abstract

Optimal power flow (OPF) problems are non-convex and large-scale optimization problems with important applications in power networks. This paper proposes the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm to solve a distributed semidefinite programming (SDP) formulation of the OPF problem. In this formulation, every agent seeks to solve a local optimization with its own cost function, physical constraints on its nodal power injection, voltage, and power flow of the lines it is connected to, and decision constraints on variables shared with neighbors to ensure consistency of the obtained solution. In the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm, every pair of connected nodes in the electrical network update their local variables in an alternating fashion. This strategy is asynchronous, in the sense that no clock synchronization is required, and relies on an orientation of the electrical network that prescribes the precise ordering of node updates. We establish the asymptotic convergence properties to the primal-dual optimizer when the orientation is acyclic. Given the dependence of the convergence rate on the network orientation, we also develop a distributed graph coloring algorithm that finds an orientation with diameter at most five for electrical networks with geometric degree distribution. Simulations illustrate our results on various IEEE bus test cases.

I Introduction

The optimal power flow (OPF) problem seeks to minimize the cost of electricity generation subject to voltage and power flow constraints. Finding a solution to the OPF problem is challenging due to its large-scale and non-convex nature and, therefore, it is typically solved off-line for centralized planning of power networks. However, recent technological advances involving the integration of renewable distributed energy resources introduce higher operational uncertainty in managing the electrical grid, motivating the need for real-time methods to solve OPF problems. Ideally, such methods should enjoy robustness against disturbances and tolerance against intermittent engagement of energy resources. An additional consideration further justifying the need for such methods is the increase of plug-and-play devices in distribution networks and the ensuing uncertain overall system configuration. Motivated by these considerations, this paper introduces a provably-correct distributed algorithm to solve a convexified OPF problem over a power network.

Literature review: Finding a global optimum of the OPF problem is challenging due to its non-convexity, so most existing algorithms only guarantee a local optimum, see e.g., [2, 3, 4]. A commonly used approach in the literature [5, 6] to convexify the problem is the use of DC power flow equations. An alternative route for the convexification of the OPF problem is employing semi-definite programming (SDP). The work [7] shows that the SDP convex relaxation on the OPF problem is exact for many networks, a fact that allows to find a global solution. Conditions on the exact convex relaxation have been further established in [8, 9]. Several recent works [10, 11] further develop SDP-based algorithms for a near-global optimal solution for OPF problems where the SDP convex relaxation does not provide a feasible solution. Relatively few works consider solving the OPF problem in a distributed way. The paper [12] proposes a distributed approach to the DC-OPF problem, where the electrical network is decomposed into several regions and each region solves its regional DC-OPF problem while iteratively matching its tie-line powers with the connected regions. The work [13] considers an SDP-based convexification of the OPF problem and then proposes gradient-based primal-dual algorithm which displays fast convergence to the optimum in simulation studies. The algorithm design is limited to voltage magnitude constraints and linear objective functions and does not incorporate constraints on the active/reactive power. The work [14] also considers a SDP-based relaxation of the OPF problem, partitions a so-called weakly-meshed network into several areas so that the “macro” graph describing the interconnected areas has a tree topology, and applies the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) to solve the distributed optimization associated with the macro graph. In general, gradient-based methods are amenable to asynchronous implementations, but have a rate of convergence O​(log⁡(n)/n)𝑂𝑛𝑛O(\log(n)/n) or slower [15]. In comparison, ADMM is faster with a O​(1/n)𝑂1𝑛O(1/n) convergence rate [16], while requiring a synchronous implementation. Drawing connections with the increasing body of work on gossiping in network systems [17, 18, 19], our algorithm design prescribes pairwise updates between neighboring agents to avoid the requirement of clock synchronization while enjoying similar convergence properties as ADMM.

Statement of contributions: Our starting point for the algorithm design is the formulation of a distributed version of the OPF problem, where each bus (node) plays the role of an agent with computation and communication capabilities. Every node creates local copies of the voltage of the neighboring nodes which are physically connected to it. Each node poses an optimization with its local cost function, constraints of its nodal power injection and voltage, and constraints associated with the power flow of the connected lines. On top of those local physical constraints, every node also has equality constraints sharing to its neighbors to ensure that every copy of the variables coincides. We then consider the convexification of this distributed OPF formulation using semi-definite programming (SDP). Our first contribution is the synthesis of the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm to solve the distributed OPF formulation in a distributed way. In our design, every pair of connected buses solves their local optimization problem in an ADMM-like, alternating fashion. To establish the order of such alternating iterations across the network, every bus only updates its variables when all the neighboring buses have finished an update later than its last update. This logic does not require any clock synchronization between the agents, in contrast to ADMM. Our second contribution is the convergence analysis of the proposed scheduled-asynchronous algorithm. Under reasonable assumptions on the data defining the optimization problem and the requirement than the graph orientation is acyclic (to avoid “locked” situations where every bus is waiting for an update from at least one of its neighbors), we employ the LaSalle Invariance Principle to establish the convergence to the primal-dual solution. Given the dependence of the algorithm convergence on the orientation of the network graph, our third contribution concerns the optimal selection of this orientation. In fact, the time need for all agents to finish at least one update is directly related to the diameter of the oriented network graph, and hence it is desirable to minimize it. In general, finding an orientation that minimizes the diameter is equivalent to finding the chromatic number of the graph, which is NP-hard. We design a distributed graph coloring algorithm that finds an orientation with diameter at most five for electrical networks with geometric degree distribution. The distributed nature of this strategy makes it naturally robust to changes in the network topology. Simulations on various IEEE bus test cases of the combined graph coloring and scheduled-asynchronous algorithms illustrate the performance and robustness of the proposed design.

Organization: Section II presents basic concepts and notation. Section III introduces the OPF problem and its distributed formulation. Section IV presents the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm and analyzes its convergence properties. Section V introduces a distributed graph coloring algorithm to obtain an acyclic orientation of small diameter. Section VI illustrates the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm in benchmark IEEE test cases. Finally, we gather our conclusions in Section VII.

II Preliminaries

This section introduces basic notation and concepts from graph theory and optimization.

II-A Notation

We denote by ℕℕ\operatorname{\mathbb{N}}, and ℂℂ\mathbb{C} the sets of positive integers, reals and complex numbers, respectively. We denote by |𝒩|𝒩|\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}| the cardinality of the set 𝒩𝒩\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}. For a complex number a∈ℂ𝑎ℂa\in\mathbb{C}, we let |a|𝑎|a| and ∠​a∠𝑎\angle a be the complex modulus and angle of a𝑎a. The 222-norm of a complex vector v∈ℂn𝑣superscriptℂ𝑛v\in\mathbb{C}^{n} is written as ‖v‖norm𝑣\|v\|. Let 𝕊+⊂ℂn×nsubscript𝕊superscriptℂ𝑛𝑛\mathbb{S}_{+}\subset\mathbb{C}^{n\times n} and ℋn⊂𝕊+superscriptℋ𝑛subscript𝕊\mathcal{H}^{n}\subset\mathbb{S}_{+} be the set of positive semidefinite and n𝑛n-dimensional Hermitian matrices, respectively. For A∈ℂn×n𝐴superscriptℂ𝑛𝑛A\in\mathbb{C}^{n\times n}, we let A∗superscript𝐴A^{*} be its conjugate transpose and 𝐓𝐫⁡{A}𝐓𝐫𝐴\operatorname{\bf Tr}\{A\} be its trace. For A,B∈ℋn𝐴𝐵superscriptℋ𝑛A,B\in\mathcal{H}^{n}, we denote their inner product by ⟨A,B⟩=𝐓𝐫⁡{A​B}𝐴𝐵𝐓𝐫𝐴𝐵\langle A,B\rangle=\operatorname{\bf Tr}\{AB\}. We use ▽F▽𝐹{\bigtriangledown}F to denote the gradient of the scalar function F𝐹F.

II-B Graph Theory

We review basic notions of graph theory following [20]. A graph is a pair 𝒢=(𝒩,ℰ)𝒢𝒩ℰ\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}=(\operatorname{\mathcal{N}},\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}), where 𝒩⊆ℕ𝒩ℕ\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}\subseteq\operatorname{\mathbb{N}} is its set of vertices or nodes and ℰ⊆𝒩×𝒩ℰ𝒩𝒩\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}\subseteq\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}\times\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} is its set of edges. A loop is an edge that connects a vertex to itself. Two nodes i,k∈𝒩𝑖𝑘𝒩i,k\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} are connected if {i,k}∈ℰ𝑖𝑘ℰ\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}. The graph is undirected if {i,k}={k,i}∈ℰ𝑖𝑘𝑘𝑖ℰ\{i,k\}=\{k,i\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}. The local neighborhood of a node k𝑘k in an undirected graph is 𝒩k:={l∈𝒩|{l,k}∈ℰ}∪{k}assignsubscript𝒩𝑘conditional-set𝑙𝒩𝑙𝑘ℰ𝑘\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{k}:=\{l\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}\;|\;\{l,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}\}\cup\{k\}. The degree of a node k𝑘k is |𝒩k|−1subscript𝒩𝑘1|\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{k}|-1. In a directed graph, each pair of vertices in ℰℰ\operatorname{\mathcal{E}} is ordered such that the corresponding edge {i,k}𝑖𝑘\{i,k\} has a direction, with i𝑖i and k𝑘k distinguished as the tail and head nodes, respectively. Node i𝑖i is a source (resp. sink) if it is the tail (resp. head) node of all the edges it belongs to. Node k𝑘k is an out-neighbor of node i𝑖i if {i,k}∈ℰ𝑖𝑘ℰ\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}. The out-degree of node i𝑖i is defined as |{k∈𝒩|{i,k}∈ℰ}|conditional-set𝑘𝒩𝑖𝑘ℰ|\{k\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}|\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}\}|. A path in a (directed or undirected) graph is a sequence of vertices such that any two consecutive nodes correspond to an edge of the graph. The length of a path is the number of its corresponding edges. The diameter of a graph is the maximum length of the shortest path connecting any two graph vertices in the graph. A cycle is a path whose first and last vertices are the same. A graph is acyclic if it contains no cycles. An orientation of an undirected graph is an assignment of exactly one direction to each of its edges. A graph orientation is acyclic if the resulting directed graph is acyclic. A graph is bipartite if the set of its vertices can be decomposed into two disjoint subsets such that, within each one, no two vertices are connected.

A simple graph is a graph with no loops nor multiple edges connecting any pair of two vertices. A planar graph is a graph that can be drawn on the plane in a way that its edges intersect only at their endpoints. A vertex-induced subgraph of 𝒢=(𝒩,ℰ)𝒢𝒩ℰ\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}=(\operatorname{\mathcal{N}},\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}), written as 𝒢s⁡[𝒩s]subscript𝒢𝑠subscript𝒩𝑠\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}_{s}[\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s}], is a subgraph of 𝒢𝒢\operatorname{\mathcal{G}} with the set of nodes 𝒩s⊆𝒩subscript𝒩𝑠𝒩\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s}\subseteq\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} and set of edges ℰs=ℰ∩(𝒩s×𝒩s)subscriptℰ𝑠ℰsubscript𝒩𝑠subscript𝒩𝑠\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}_{s}=\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}\cap(\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s}\times\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{s}). A chordal graph is a graph that does not contain an induced cycle of length greater than four. Graph coloring consists of assigning a color to every node in the graph in such a way that any pair of connected nodes have different colors. The smallest number of colors needed to color a graph G𝐺G is called its chromatic number.

Strong duality holds if p⋆=d⋆superscript𝑝⋆superscript𝑑⋆p^{\star}=d^{\star}. Slater’s condition implies that strong duality holds.

III Problem Formulation

This section introduces the problem of interest. We begin with a general formulation of the optimal power flow (OPF) problem over an electrical network. We then consider its convex relaxation and rewrite it as the combination of several smaller-scale interconnected convex subproblems. The resulting semidefinite programming (SDP) problem is the starting point for our distributed algorithm design.

Consider an electrical network graph with generation buses 𝒩Gsubscript𝒩𝐺\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{G}, load buses 𝒩Lsubscript𝒩𝐿\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{L}, and electrical interconnections described by an undirected edge set ℰℰ\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}. Let 𝒩=𝒩G∪𝒩L𝒩subscript𝒩𝐺subscript𝒩𝐿\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}=\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{G}\cup\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{L} and denote its cardinality by N𝑁N. We denote the phasor voltage at bus i𝑖i by Vi=Ei​ej​θisubscript𝑉𝑖subscript𝐸𝑖superscript𝑒𝑗subscript𝜃𝑖V_{i}=E_{i}e^{j\theta_{i}}, where Ei∈ℝsubscript𝐸𝑖ℝE_{i}\in\mathbb{R} and θi∈[−π,π)subscript𝜃𝑖𝜋𝜋\theta_{i}\in[-\pi,\pi) are the voltage magnitude and phase angle, respectively. When convenient, we let V={Vi|i∈𝒩}𝑉conditional-setsubscript𝑉𝑖𝑖𝒩V=\{V_{i}\;|\;i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}\} denote the collection of voltages at all buses. Constraints (6a-6d) come from Eq. (III). The combined constraints W⪰0succeeds-or-equals𝑊0W\succeq 0 and rank⁡(W)=1rank𝑊1\operatorname{rank}(W)=1 in (6e) correspond to writing the voltage as a matrix variable. The elimination of the rank constraint gives rise to the convex relaxation of the OPF problem.

Following the exposition in [23], we next reformulate the OPF problem in a distributed way as follows. We start from the observation that every constraint except Eq. (6e) in (P1) is either related to the power injection at one bus or the voltage difference between connected buses. In addition, the power injection at one bus is only related to the voltage of the buses it is connected to. This property is embedded in the structure of the non-zero entries of the admittance matrix in (3). As a consequence, we can rewrite the constraints (6a-6d) in terms of variables Wi∈ℋNisubscript𝑊𝑖superscriptℋsubscript𝑁𝑖W_{i}\in\mathcal{H}^{N_{i}} for all i∈𝒩⁡𝑖𝒩i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}\textbf{}, where Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i} is quadratic in the voltage variables corresponding to the local neighborhood 𝒩isubscript𝒩𝑖\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{i} in the electrical network graph, and Ni=|𝒩i|subscript𝑁𝑖subscript𝒩𝑖N_{i}=|\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{i}|. In this way, we obtain

where i^^𝑖\hat{i} refers the row (or column) of the matrix associated with bus i𝑖i (note that Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i} and Wksubscript𝑊𝑘W_{k} might have different dimensions). For chordal graphs, (P2) with the additional non-convex rank constraints, rank⁡(Wi)=1ranksubscript𝑊𝑖1\operatorname{rank}(W_{i})=1, ∀i∈𝒩for-all𝑖𝒩\forall i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} is equivalent to (P1), see [24]. For general graphs, (P2) with the rank constraints does not necessarily give an optimal solution of (P1), but simulations indicate [25] that (P2) has a low-rank solution whose value is close to the optimal value of (P1). In the rest of the paper, we assume that a unique optimal solution of (P2) exists, and we denote it as (W𝒩⋆,p⋆)subscriptsuperscript𝑊⋆𝒩superscript𝑝⋆(W^{\star}_{\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}},p^{\star}).

Our objective in this paper is to design a distributed algorithm to solve (P2). We view each bus of the electrical network as a computing agent that can communicate with any other bus which is physically connected to. By distributed, we mean that each agent only requires information from neighboring buses that share their local variables to implement the algorithm. By solving the optimization problem, we mean that each bus eventually finds its own optimal allocation (not the optimal allocation for the whole electrical network). When considered collectively, the local optimal allocation with agreement on the shared variables yields the complete optimal solution.

IV The Scheduled-Asynchronous Algorithm

In this section, we first provide a design rationale for the scheduled-asynchronous distributed algorithm and then introduce it formally. We next proceed to characterize the algorithm convergence properties.

IV-A Rationale for Algorithm Design

For convenience of exposition, we start by rewriting the optimization (P2). For a network with an arbitrary number of buses, one can view the optimization as a combination of multiple two-bus sub-problems. This viewpoint inspires the following algorithm design. Note that, according to (12), for every edge (i.e., for every two-bus sub-problem), the tail node performs first the update, followed by the head node. In other words, the orientation 𝒢^=(𝒩,ℰ^)^𝒢𝒩^ℰ\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}}=(\operatorname{\mathcal{N}},\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}) encodes the natural ordering of updating by the terminal nodes present in the ADMM algorithm. Under the proposed design, the difference in the number of iterations made between two connected nodes is at most one due to the alternating execution. For each pair of connected nodes i𝑖i and k𝑘k such that {i,k}∈ℰ^𝑖𝑘^ℰ\{i,k\}\in\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}, each of them updates the corresponding Lagrange multiplier according to

pi​kt+=pi​kt+ρi​k​Gi​k​(Wit+,Wkt+).superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑘superscript𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑘𝑡subscript𝜌𝑖𝑘subscript𝐺𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖superscript𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘superscript𝑡\displaystyle p_{ik}^{t^{+}}=p_{ik}^{t}+\rho_{ik}G_{ik}(W_{i}^{t^{+}},W_{k}^{t^{+}}). (13)

Updating pi​kt+superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑘superscript𝑡p_{ik}^{t^{+}} locally at the terminal nodes can reduce the communication burden and enhances robustness. We denote pt={pi​kt,{i,k}∈ℰ}∈4​|ℰ|superscript𝑝𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑖𝑘𝑖𝑘ℰsuperscript4ℰabsentp^{t}=\{p^{t}_{ik},\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}\}\in^{4|\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}|} and ρ∈|ℰ|×|ℰ|superscriptℰℰ𝜌absent\rho\in^{|\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}|\times|\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}|} be the diagonal matrix such that each diagonal element corresponds to ρi​ksubscript𝜌𝑖𝑘\rho_{ik} of one unique link in ℰℰ\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}. Algorithm 1 below presents formally the proposed strategy.

In Algorithm 1, each bus i𝑖i only does its optimization after it has received new updates from all its neighbors k∈𝒩i𝑘subscript𝒩𝑖k\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{i} since the last iteration. The stopping criteria is given by the scale of the violation of the equality constraints,

γit+=∑{i,k}∈ℰ^‖Gi​k​(Wit+,Wkt)‖2+∑{k,i}∈ℰ^‖Gk​i​(Wkt+,Wit+)‖2.superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑖superscript𝑡subscript𝑖𝑘^ℰsuperscriptnormsubscript𝐺𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖superscript𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝑡2subscript𝑘𝑖^ℰsuperscriptnormsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘superscript𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖superscript𝑡2\displaystyle\gamma_{i}^{t^{+}}=\sum_{\{i,k\}\in\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}}\|G_{ik}(W_{i}^{t^{+}},W_{k}^{t})\|^{2}+\sum_{\{k,i\}\in\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}}\|G_{ki}(W_{k}^{t^{+}},W_{i}^{t^{+}})\|^{2}. (14)

This criteria is justified by the observation that if γit+=0superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑖superscript𝑡0\gamma_{i}^{t^{+}}=0, ∀i∈𝒩for-all𝑖𝒩\forall i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}, then W𝒩t+superscriptsubscript𝑊𝒩superscript𝑡W_{\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}}^{t^{+}} is the optimal solution for both (12) and (10). Using the continuity of the cost function, fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}, having γit+superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑖superscript𝑡\gamma_{i}^{t^{+}} sufficiently small for all i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} guarantees that the solution of Algorithm 1 is reasonably close to the optimum. The implementation of Algorithm 1 does not require synchronous updates between connected nodes, but involves a subtle ordering. We therefore term this strategy as the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm. Note that we use a global time index t𝑡t to time-stamp all the iterations in Algorithm 1 only for convenience. Every agent tracks the number of iterations locally, but in general does not know the global time index.

Remark IV.1.

(The orientation of the network graph must be acyclic). An important observation regarding the execution of Algorithm 1 is that the orientation 𝒢^^𝒢\mathcal{\hat{G}} given to the electrical network graph must be free of cycles. Otherwise, given the meaning encoded by the orientation of each edge, a deadlock would occur: every node at the cycle would be waiting for the update from a neighboring node in the cycle. There are various ways in which the network can determine an acyclic orientation in a distributed way. For instance, if every node has a unique identity k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N}, then, for each edge in ℰℰ\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}, one can designate the node with the smallest identity as the tail and the other node as the head. The resulting graph 𝒢^^𝒢\mathcal{\hat{G}} is acyclic [27]. We revisit this point in Section V below. □□\square

Remark IV.2.

(The scheduled-asynchronous algorithm as a single-valued map). The scheduled-asynchronous algorithm is, in general, a set-valued map due to the argmin operator in (12). However, we argue here that it can be seen as a single-valued map upon further examination of (12). Notice that, except for the constraint Wi⪰0succeeds-or-equalssubscript𝑊𝑖0W_{i}\succeq 0, all the other constraints and the objective function of (12) are only related to the entries associated with the star network centered at node i𝑖i. We illustrate the meaning of entries associated with a star network in an example with 555 nodes. For W1subscript𝑊1W_{1}, its diagonal, first column, and first row elements are the entries associated with the star network centered at node one.

W1subscript𝑊1\displaystyle W_{1} =[W1​(1,1)W1​(1,2)⋯W1​(1,5)W1​(2,1)W1​(2,2)W1​(2,5)⋮⋱⋮W1​(5,1)W1​(5,2)⋯W1​(5,5)]absentmatrixsubscript𝑊111subscript𝑊112⋯subscript𝑊115subscript𝑊121subscript𝑊122missing-subexpressionsubscript𝑊125⋮missing-subexpression⋱⋮subscript𝑊151subscript𝑊152⋯subscript𝑊155\displaystyle=\begin{bmatrix}W_{1}(1,1)&W_{1}(1,2)&\cdots&W_{1}(1,5)\\ W_{1}(2,1)&W_{1}(2,2)&&W_{1}(2,5)\\ \vdots&&\ddots&\vdots\\ W_{1}(5,1)&W_{1}(5,2)&\cdots&W_{1}(5,5)\end{bmatrix}

We refer to the entries of Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i} that are not associated with the star network centered at node i𝑖i as “irrelevant”, because those entries can take any value without affecting the optimal value of (12) as long as Wi⪰0succeeds-or-equalssubscript𝑊𝑖0W_{i}\succeq 0 remains satisfied. Without loss of generality, Algorithm 1 can always assign zeros to the irrelevant entries. Such assignment makes Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i} a Hermitian matrix associated with a star network, and [23, Proposition 3] ensures that Wi⪰0succeeds-or-equalssubscript𝑊𝑖0W_{i}\succeq 0. The manipulation above makes the objective function of (12) strongly convex on the decision variables (irrelevant entries are considered as constants) due to the quadratic terms in (12b) and (12c). This observation justifies the interpretation of the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm as a single-valued map F:𝒲×4​|ℰ^|→𝒲×4​|ℰ^|F:\operatorname{\mathcal{W}}\times^{4|\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}|}\rightarrow\operatorname{\mathcal{W}}\times^{4|\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}|} with 𝒲:=𝒲1×𝒲2×⋯×𝒲Nassign𝒲subscript𝒲1subscript𝒲2⋯subscript𝒲𝑁\operatorname{\mathcal{W}}:=\operatorname{\mathcal{W}}_{1}\times\operatorname{\mathcal{W}}_{2}\times\cdots\times\operatorname{\mathcal{W}}_{N}. □□\square

IV-B Convergence Analysis

The analysis of the convergence properties of the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm requires a careful consideration of the asynchronous updates of the nodes. In what follows and for convenience, we view the time index of the decision variables as an iteration index. For each bus i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}, let ti​(n)subscript𝑡𝑖𝑛t_{i}(n) be the time index at which i𝑖i has exactly performed n𝑛n number of the minimizations described in (12). By definition, for each n𝑛n, we have Wit=Witi​(n)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖subscript𝑡𝑖𝑛W_{i}^{t}=W_{i}^{t_{i}(n)}, for ti​(n)≤t<ti​(n+1)subscript𝑡𝑖𝑛𝑡subscript𝑡𝑖𝑛1t_{i}(n)\leq t<t_{i}(n+1). With a slight abuse of notation, in the following we use the shorthand notation Winsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖𝑛W_{i}^{n}, pinsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑛p_{i}^{n} and rinsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑛r_{i}^{n} instead of the corresponding Witi​(n)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖subscript𝑡𝑖𝑛W_{i}^{t_{i}(n)}, piti​(n)superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑡𝑖𝑛p_{i}^{t_{i}(n)} and riti​(n)superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖subscript𝑡𝑖𝑛r_{i}^{t_{i}(n)}, where rt={ri​kt,{i,k}∈ℰ^}∈4​|ℰ^|superscript𝑟𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑘𝑡𝑖𝑘^ℰsuperscript4^ℰabsentr^{t}=\{r_{ik}^{t}\;,\;\{i,k\}\in\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}\}\in^{4|\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}|} and ri​kt=Gi​k​(Wit,Wkt)superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑘𝑡subscript𝐺𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝑡r_{ik}^{t}=G_{ik}(W_{i}^{t},W_{k}^{t}). With all the elements in place, we next establish the convergence properties of Algorithm 1.

Theorem IV.3.

(Convergence of Algorithm 1). Assume the following conditions hold

  1. 1.

    the cost functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}, i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}, are convex,

  2. 2.

    (P2) is feasible and Slater’s condition holds,

    the optimal Lagrange multipliers are bounded, p⋆<∞superscript𝑝⋆p^{\star}<\infty,

  4. 4.

    the orientation 𝒢^^𝒢\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}} is acyclic.

Then, the sequence (W𝒩n,pn)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝒩𝑛superscript𝑝𝑛(W_{\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}}^{n},p^{n}) generated by Algorithm 1 converges to the optimal primal-dual pair (W𝒩⋆,p⋆)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝒩⋆superscript𝑝⋆(W_{\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}}^{\star},p^{\star}) as n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty.

Our proof strategy consists of employing the LaSalle’s Invariance Principle for discrete-time systems, [Theorem 1.19] in [20]. To this goal, we will justify that all the assumptions of the LaSalle’s theorem hold. First, according to Remark IV.2, we can view F𝐹F as a single-valued mapping without loss of generality. Furthermore, F𝐹F is continuous due to maximum theorem and condition 1). We next consider the candidate LaSalle function

Bounded Trajectories. We next justify that the trajectories of Algorithm 1 are bounded. According to (A.39), the primal variable W𝒩nsubscriptsuperscript𝑊𝑛𝒩W^{n}_{\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}} always evolves in a compact set 𝒲𝒲\operatorname{\mathcal{W}} and therefore is bounded. To show that the evolution of pnsuperscript𝑝𝑛p^{n} is also bounded, we can reason by contradiction. If it were not, then the sequence V​(Wn,pn)𝑉superscript𝑊𝑛superscript𝑝𝑛V(W^{n},p^{n}) would go to infinity, and this would contradict the fact that the sublevel sets of V𝑉V are invariant (which is as a consequence of (16)).

Application of LaSalle Invariance Principle. Remark IV.4.

(Convergence rate of Algorithm 1). Characterizing the convergence rate of the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm is challenging. The main reason for this is the fact that, given the particular characteristics of the design of Algorithm 1, the proof of Theorem IV.3 identifies a LaSalle function, and not a Lyapunov one. This is in contrast with the convergence proof of ADMM, cf., [16], where the availability of a Lyapunov function makes the convergence analysis and the rate characterization easier. If the network topology is bipartite, Algorithm 1 reduces to ADMM and hence shares the O​(1/n)𝑂1𝑛O(1/n) convergence rate established in [16]. Based on this and our simulation results, we conjecture that Algorithm 1 also has O​(1/n)𝑂1𝑛O(1/n) convergence rate with a smaller constant. □□\square

Remark IV.5.

(Heterogeneous selection of parameter ρ𝜌\rho). The convergence rate of Algorithm 1 depends on the parameter ρ𝜌\rho which weighs how the errors in the constraint satisfaction affect the evolution of the dual variables. Our simulation studies show that selecting ρi​ksubscript𝜌𝑖𝑘\rho_{ik} heterogeneously can improve the convergence rate dramatically. In particular, we observe that choosing ρi​ksubscript𝜌𝑖𝑘\rho_{ik} proportionally to the norm of the complex line admittance of edge {i,k}𝑖𝑘\{i,k\}, ‖yi​k‖normsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑘\|y_{ik}\| improves the convergence rate compared to selecting a uniform ρ𝜌\rho, i.e., ρi​k=ρ0,∀{i,k}∈ℰformulae-sequencesubscript𝜌𝑖𝑘subscript𝜌0for-all𝑖𝑘ℰ\rho_{ik}=\rho_{0},\forall\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}. The intuition behind this fact is that the network is more sensitive to the perturbation on the edges with larger admittances. To justify this point, consider an edge where Gi​ksubscript𝐺𝑖𝑘G_{ik} in (9) is not zero,

Gi​k​(Wit,Wkt)=δi​kt,∀{i,k}∈ℰ^,formulae-sequencesubscript𝐺𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑘𝑡for-all𝑖𝑘^ℰ\displaystyle G_{ik}(W_{i}^{t},W_{k}^{t})=\delta_{ik}^{t},\;\forall\{i,k\}\in\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}, (28)

with 0≠δi​kt∈40superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑘𝑡superscript4absent0\neq\delta_{ik}^{t}\in^{4}. Due to (28), W𝒩tsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝒩𝑡W_{\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}}^{t} is not a feasible solution of (P2). Consider then the virtual network in Fig. 1, where nodes i𝑖i and k𝑘k are not physically connected and only the communication between them remains.

Node i𝑖i is connected to a virtual node kvsubscript𝑘𝑣k_{v} with admittance yi​ksubscript𝑦𝑖𝑘y_{ik}, and the same applies to k𝑘k and ivsubscript𝑖𝑣i_{v}. The communication between i𝑖i and k𝑘k have Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i} and Wksubscript𝑊𝑘W_{k} satisfy Gi​k​(Wit,Wkt)=δi​ktsubscript𝐺𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑘𝑡G_{ik}(W_{i}^{t},W_{k}^{t})=\delta_{ik}^{t}. Let Vi​i^subscript𝑉𝑖^𝑖V_{i\hat{i}} and Vi​k^subscript𝑉𝑖^𝑘V_{i\hat{k}}, respectively, denote the copy of the voltages of bus i𝑖i and k𝑘k contained in Wisubscript𝑊𝑖W_{i}. Assign to nodes kvsubscript𝑘𝑣k_{v} and ivsubscript𝑖𝑣i_{v} the voltages Vi​k^subscript𝑉𝑖^𝑘V_{i\hat{k}} and Vk​i^subscript𝑉𝑘^𝑖V_{k\hat{i}}, respectively. In this way, the virtual network has the power flow from kvsubscript𝑘𝑣k_{v} to i𝑖i given by

Vi​k^​(yi​k​(Vi​k^−Vi​i^))∗.subscript𝑉𝑖^𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑘subscript𝑉𝑖^𝑘subscript𝑉𝑖^𝑖\displaystyle V_{i\hat{k}}\Big{(}y_{ik}(V_{i\hat{k}}-V_{i\hat{i}})\Big{)}^{*}. (29)

On the other hand, the power flow from k𝑘k to ivsubscript𝑖𝑣i_{v} is

Vk​k^​(yi​k​(Vk​k^−Vk​i^))∗.subscript𝑉𝑘^𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑘subscript𝑉𝑘^𝑘subscript𝑉𝑘^𝑖\displaystyle V_{k\hat{k}}\Big{(}y_{ik}(V_{k\hat{k}}-V_{k\hat{i}})\Big{)}^{*}. (30)

The copies of voltages of nodes i𝑖i and k𝑘k are related by

Vi​k^t=Vk​k^t+δ^i​k,kt,Vi​i^t=Vk​i^t+δ^i​k,it,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖^𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑘^𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝛿𝑖𝑘𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖^𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑘^𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝛿𝑖𝑘𝑖𝑡\displaystyle V_{i\hat{k}}^{t}=V_{k\hat{k}}^{t}+\hat{\delta}_{ik,k}^{t},\quad V_{i\hat{i}}^{t}=V_{k\hat{i}}^{t}+\hat{\delta}_{ik,i}^{t}, (31)

where δ^i​k,kt=|δi​kt​(1)|​exp⁡(j​∠​(δi​kt​(3)+j​δi​kt​(4)))subscriptsuperscript^𝛿𝑡𝑖𝑘𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑘𝑡1𝑗∠subscriptsuperscript𝛿𝑡𝑖𝑘3𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝛿𝑡𝑖𝑘4\hat{\delta}^{t}_{ik,k}=\sqrt{|\delta_{ik}^{t}(1)|}\exp(j\angle{(\delta^{t}_{ik}(3)+j\delta^{t}_{ik}(4))}) and δ^i​k,it=|δi​kt​(2)|subscriptsuperscript^𝛿𝑡𝑖𝑘𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝛿𝑡𝑖𝑘2\hat{\delta}^{t}_{ik,i}=\sqrt{|\delta^{t}_{ik}(2)|} (assume ∠​Vi=0∠subscript𝑉𝑖0\angle{V_{i}}=0 without loss of generality). If δi​kt=0superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑘𝑡0\delta_{ik}^{t}=0, then the values of (29) and (30) are the same because Vi​k^=Vk​k^subscript𝑉𝑖^𝑘subscript𝑉𝑘^𝑘V_{i\hat{k}}=V_{k\hat{k}} and Vi​i^=Vk​i^subscript𝑉𝑖^𝑖subscript𝑉𝑘^𝑖V_{i\hat{i}}=V_{k\hat{i}}. Therefore, the virtual network is equivalent to the original one if δi​kt=0superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑘𝑡0\delta_{ik}^{t}=0. On the other hand, if the first two elements of δi​ktsuperscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑘𝑡\delta_{ik}^{t} are non-zero, then Vi​k^t≠Vk​k^tsuperscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖^𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑘^𝑘𝑡V_{i\hat{k}}^{t}\neq V_{k\hat{k}}^{t} and Vi​k^t≠Vk​i^tsuperscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖^𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑘^𝑖𝑡V_{i\hat{k}}^{t}\neq V_{k\hat{i}}^{t} according to (31). In such case, the virtual network is not equivalent to the original one. Furthermore, we observe that for a given non-zero δi​ktsuperscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑘𝑡\delta_{ik}^{t}, the discrepancy between Eq. (29) and (30) is proportional to yi​ksubscript𝑦𝑖𝑘y_{ik}. This discrepancy has the interpretation of a perturbation on the apparent power flow for edge {i,k}𝑖𝑘\{i,k\}. □□\square

V Directed Graph Design

Here, we first describe how the average time between two consecutive iterations under the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm for a node depends on the diameter of the orientation of the network graph. Motivated by this observation, we set out to find an acyclic orientation with minimal diameter in a distributed fashion. In general, finding such an orientation is equivalent to finding the chromatic number, which is NP-hard. However, exploiting the planar property of many power networks, we develop a distributed algorithm to determine an orientation with small diameter.

V-A Relationship Between Graph Coloring and Diameter

The updating sequence of the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm depends on the orientation 𝒢^=(𝒩,ℰ^)^𝒢𝒩^ℰ\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}}=(\operatorname{\mathcal{N}},\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}}). To see this, consider a path in 𝒢^^𝒢\hat{\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}}, with i𝑖i being the initial node and k𝑘k the end node. The update of k𝑘k requires that all other nodes in the path finish at least an update before it, which are processed in sequence starting from node i𝑖i. The “waiting time” of node k𝑘k associated to this path corresponds therefore to its length. Since the diameter of the orientation bounds the length of all the paths, this justifies finding an acyclic orientation which the smallest diameter. We formalize this problem next. Let Ω​(𝒢)Ω𝒢\Omega(\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}) be the collection of all acyclic orientations of 𝒢𝒢\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}. We denote by 𝒢ωsubscript𝒢𝜔\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}_{\omega} the directed graph corresponding to ω∈Ω​(𝒢)𝜔Ω𝒢\omega\in\Omega(\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}). The problem we aim to solve is

ω⋆=arg​minω∈Ω​(𝒢)⁡(maxh∈𝒫ω⁡|h|),superscript𝜔⋆argsubscript𝜔Ω𝒢subscriptℎsubscript𝒫𝜔ℎ\displaystyle\omega^{\star}=\text{arg}\min_{\omega\in\Omega(\operatorname{\mathcal{G}})}\big{(}\max_{h\in\mathcal{P}_{\omega}}|h|\big{)}, (32)

where 𝒫ωsubscript𝒫𝜔\mathcal{P}_{\omega} is the set of paths in 𝒢ωsubscript𝒢𝜔\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}_{\omega}, and |h|ℎ|h| is the length of the path hℎh. The optimization (32) is directly related to the classical problem of finding the chromatic number 𝒳⁡(𝒢)𝒳𝒢\operatorname{\mathcal{X}}(\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}) of an undirected graph 𝒢𝒢\operatorname{\mathcal{G}} [28]. In fact, one has

𝒳⁡(𝒢)=1+minω∈Ω​(𝒢)⁡(maxh∈𝒫ω⁡|h|).𝒳𝒢1subscript𝜔Ω𝒢subscriptℎsubscript𝒫𝜔ℎ\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathcal{X}}(\operatorname{\mathcal{G}})=1+\min_{\omega\in\Omega(\operatorname{\mathcal{G}})}\big{(}\max_{h\in\mathcal{P}_{\omega}}|h|\big{)}. (33)

In general, computing 𝒳⁡(𝒢)𝒳𝒢\operatorname{\mathcal{X}}(\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}) is NP-hard, see e.g. [29]. There are only approximate algorithms to find a solution, see for example [30]. However, for planar graphs, the chromatic number is upper bounded by four [31] and, furthermore, there exists a quadratic-time algorithm to find a graph-coloring with four colors, cf. [32]. Fortunately, the following assumption holds for most electrical networks.

Assumption 1.

(Planar network topology [33]). Electrical networks have simple planar network topology.

If a centralized entity has information on the network topology, then the algorithm in [32] can be run to assign a number (or color) to every agent. This procedure might be problematic in large-scale scenarios, specially in the presence of plug-and-play devices that easily change the network topology. This motivates our design of a distributed algorithm.

V-B Distributed Orientation Computation with Small Diameter

The following distributed algorithm from [34] finds an orientation of an arbitrary planar graph with diameter bounded by five (or equivalently 𝒳⁡(𝒢)≤6𝒳𝒢6\operatorname{\mathcal{X}}(\operatorname{\mathcal{G}})\leq 6):

  1. 1.

    find an acyclic orientation in a distributed way such that every node has out-degree at most five.

  2. 2.

    every node chooses a color that is different from all the out-neighboring nodes defined in step 1).

Note that any ordering of the colors induces an orientation of the graph, which is furthermore acyclic, cf. Remark IV.1. The algorithm above is simple to implement but may be conservative for electrical networks because, in general, the degree of most nodes is far less than six. In fact, empirical studies [35, 36] have shown that electrical networks have a degree distribution that follows the exponential distribution. Since the degree takes integer values, it is more appropriate to characterize the degree distribution with the geometric distribution – the discrete analogy of the exponential distribution.

Assumption 2.

(Geometric degree distribution). In electrical networks, the number of nodes with degree at least d0∈ℕsubscript𝑑0ℕd_{0}\in\operatorname{\mathbb{N}} satisfies

Prob​(d=d0)=λ​(1−λ)d0,Prob𝑑subscript𝑑0𝜆superscript1𝜆subscript𝑑0\displaystyle\text{Prob}(d=d_{0})=\lambda(1-\lambda)^{d_{0}}, (34)

with parameter 0≤λ≤10𝜆10\leq\lambda\leq 1.

Most nodes have small degree due to (34). According to [35, 37], the average degree of empirical electrical networks is between 222 and 333. Many electrical networks, as a result, have the chromatic number far less than six. For example, IEEE 14, 30 and 57 bus test cases have 𝒳⁡(𝒢)=3𝒳𝒢3\operatorname{\mathcal{X}}(\operatorname{\mathcal{G}})=3. Therefore, it is conceivable that one can find an orientation with diameter less than five. Motivated by this observation, we modify the algorithm in [34] to exploit the geometric degree distribution property.

We propose Algorithm 2 to find a preliminary orientation. The idea is to first try to find an orientation with the out-degree of all nodes no bigger than 2. If this is not possible, then the strategy searches instead for an orientation with one more out-degree. If necessary, this process is repeated until Algorithm 2 eventually finds an orientation where the out-degree of all nodes is at most five.

We next explain the pseudocode of Algorithm 2. Every node i𝑖i starts with an initial number ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i} such that ηi≠ηksubscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝜂𝑘\eta_{i}\neq\eta_{k}, for all {i,k}∈ℰ𝑖𝑘ℰ\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}. These numbers induce an acyclic orientation by declaring that node i𝑖i is a tail of {i,k}𝑖𝑘\{i,k\} if ηi<ηksubscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝜂𝑘\eta_{i}<\eta_{k}, cf. Remark IV.1. Under the algorithm, every node i𝑖i recursively updates ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i} if its current out-degree is bigger than or equal to a number h¯isubscript¯ℎ𝑖\overline{h}_{i}, initially set to h¯0=2superscript¯ℎ02\overline{h}^{0}=2, for all i𝑖i. The update of ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i} follows a simple rule to choose a number bigger than ηksubscript𝜂𝑘\eta_{k}, for all k∈𝒩i𝑘subscript𝒩𝑖k\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{i}. In this way, node i𝑖i becomes a sink node with out-degree zero in the new induced orientation. Node i𝑖i then sends ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i} to all k∈𝒩i𝑘subscript𝒩𝑖k\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{i} for them to recompute their out-degree. If all nodes do not require any further update in their η𝜂\eta, Algorithm 2 converges to an orientation in which all nodes have an out-degree of at most two. If, instead, some nodes require an update for more than m¯>1¯𝑚1\overline{m}>1 times, then the strategy has these nodes increase its h¯isubscript¯ℎ𝑖\overline{h}_{i} by one (since an orientation with out-degree less than two might not exist). Any node i𝑖i that again updates its variable m¯¯𝑚\overline{m} times has h¯isubscript¯ℎ𝑖\overline{h}_{i} increased in a similar way. The procedure repeats until every node stops updating.

The following result establishes the convergence properties of Algorithm 2.

Proposition V.1.

(Convergence of Algorithm 2). Algorithm 2 converges with h¯i≤6subscript¯ℎ𝑖6\overline{h}_{i}\leq 6 for all i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} in a finite number of iterations.

Proof.

Because m¯<∞¯𝑚\overline{m}<\infty, it is sufficient to show that every node stops updating ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i} in a finite number of steps if h¯i=6subscript¯ℎ𝑖6\overline{h}_{i}=6, ∀i∈𝒩for-all𝑖𝒩\forall i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}. Since every simple planar graph has at least one node with degree strictly less than six, this node stops updating ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i} as |𝒩ηi|≤5<h¯isubscript𝒩subscript𝜂𝑖5subscript¯ℎ𝑖|\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{\eta_{i}}|\leq 5<\overline{h}_{i}. We then consider the subgraph of 𝒢𝒢\operatorname{\mathcal{G}} induced from 𝒩∖{i}𝒩𝑖\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}\setminus\{i\}. This subgraph is also planar so we can find another node that will stop updating η𝜂\eta after a finite number of steps. The result follows by repeating this argument. ∎

With the orientation induced by the ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i} variables resulting from the algorithm, one can find a coloring of the graph with h¯:=maxi∈𝒩⁡h¯iassign¯ℎsubscript𝑖𝒩subscript¯ℎ𝑖\overline{h}:=\max_{i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}}\overline{h}_{i} colors. Given the set of numbers C:={1,2,…,h¯}assign𝐶12…¯ℎC:=\{1,2,\dots,\overline{h}\}, Algorithm 3, from [34], assigns a number in C𝐶C to each i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}. The resulting acyclic orientation has diameter at most h¯−1¯ℎ1\overline{h}-1 due to (33).

In Algorithm 2, setting m¯¯𝑚\overline{m} too small can be conservative because the strategy gives up too early in finding orientations with small diameter by rapidly increasing h¯ksubscript¯ℎ𝑘\overline{h}_{k} toward six. On the other hand, setting m¯¯𝑚\overline{m} too large slows down the convergence. The challenge lies then in characterizing the value m¯¯𝑚\overline{m} that strikes a balance between maximizing the convergence rate and minimizing the average path length of the resulting orientation. The optimal choice of m¯¯𝑚\overline{m} depends on the size of the network and the constant λ𝜆\lambda in the geometric degree distribution. Theorem V.2 illustrates how m¯¯𝑚\overline{m} is related to these factors.

Theorem V.2.

(On the degree of subgraphs and convergence of Algorithm 2). If h¯i0=c0<6superscriptsubscript¯ℎ𝑖0subscript𝑐06\overline{h}_{i}^{0}=c_{0}<6, for all i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} and m¯=∞¯𝑚\overline{m}=\infty, then Algorithm 2 converges if and only if every vertex-induced subgraph of 𝒢𝒢\operatorname{\mathcal{G}} has at least one node with degree less than c0subscript𝑐0c_{0}.

Proof.

We first show the implication from right to left. We term every node k𝑘k with degree less than c0subscript𝑐0c_{0} “stable”, because it will not update its ηksubscript𝜂𝑘\eta_{k} regardless of the change of η𝜂\eta of any other node. Let 𝒮1subscript𝒮1\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{1} be the set of stable nodes of 𝒢𝒢\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}. We then consider the induced subgraph 𝒢⁡[𝒮2]𝒢subscript𝒮2\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}[\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{2}], where 𝒮2=𝒩∖𝒮1subscript𝒮2𝒩subscript𝒮1\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{2}=\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}\setminus\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{1}. The graph 𝒢⁡[𝒮2]𝒢subscript𝒮2\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}[\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{2}] also has at least one node with degree less than c0subscript𝑐0c_{0}. Again, nodes in 𝒢⁡[𝒮2]𝒢subscript𝒮2\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}[\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{2}] with degree less than c0subscript𝑐0c_{0} are called “stable” because they will not change their η𝜂\eta in response to the change of η𝜂\eta of any other node in 𝒮2subscript𝒮2\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{2}. Every stable node i𝑖i in 𝒢⁡[𝒮2]𝒢subscript𝒮2\operatorname{\mathcal{G}}[\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{2}] updates ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i} at most once. The reason of the single update is the following. First, a stable node i𝑖i in 𝒮2subscript𝒮2\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{2} is connected to at least one node in 𝒮1subscript𝒮1\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{1}. Otherwise, node i𝑖i is in 𝒮1subscript𝒮1\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{1}. Hence, once a stable node i∈𝒮2𝑖subscript𝒮2i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{2} updates ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i}, its out-degree, |𝒩ηi|subscript𝒩subscript𝜂𝑖|\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{\eta_{i}}|, is at most h¯i−1subscript¯ℎ𝑖1\overline{h}_{i}-1 and the node will not update ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i} again. We can reason with 𝒮3,𝒮4,⋯,𝒮ssubscript𝒮3subscript𝒮4⋯subscript𝒮𝑠\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{3},\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{4},\cdots,\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{s} in a similar way until ∪α=1,2,⋯,s𝒮α=𝒩subscript𝛼12⋯𝑠subscript𝒮𝛼𝒩\cup_{\alpha=1,2,\cdots,s}\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{\alpha}=\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} (note that s<∞𝑠s<\infty because N<∞𝑁N<\infty) and conclude that Algorithm 2 converges in finite time.

Next, we show the implication from left to right. If there exists a vertex-induced subgraph with all nodes having degree at least c0subscript𝑐0c_{0}, then we can show that at least one node in the subgraph updates η𝜂\eta infinitely often. Recall that every acyclic orientation has a source node. The source of the subgraph updates its ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i} because |𝒩ηi|≥c0subscript𝒩subscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝑐0|\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{\eta_{i}}|\geq c_{0}. After this update, the orientation of the subgraph remains acyclic because it is induced by the values of the variables ηisubscript𝜂𝑖\eta_{i}. As a consequence, at least one node of the subgraph becomes a source and makes an update. The sequence repeats for infinite times because there always exists one node in the subgraph with |𝒩ηi|≥c0subscript𝒩subscript𝜂𝑖subscript𝑐0|\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}_{\eta_{i}}|\geq c_{0}. Since the number of nodes is finite, there exists at least one node that updates η𝜂\eta infinitely often. As a consequence, Algorithm 2 does not converge. ∎

Theorem V.2 provides insight into the selection of m¯¯𝑚\overline{m} in Algorithm 2. With the notation of the proof, if we set m¯=∞¯𝑚\overline{m}=\infty and Algorithm 2 converges with h¯i0=c0<6subscriptsuperscript¯ℎ0𝑖subscript𝑐06\overline{h}^{0}_{i}=c_{0}<6, for all i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}, the nodes in 𝒮αsubscript𝒮𝛼\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{\alpha} update their variables at least the number of times that nodes in 𝒮βsubscript𝒮𝛽\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{\beta} do, for β<α𝛽𝛼\beta<\alpha, because 𝒮αsubscript𝒮𝛼\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{\alpha} becomes “stable” after 𝒮βsubscript𝒮𝛽\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{\beta} does. If, instead, we choose a finite m¯¯𝑚\overline{m}, then only a subset of nodes of 𝒩𝒩\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} keep their variable h¯isubscript¯ℎ𝑖\overline{h}_{i} non-increasing, while the remaining nodes are forced to increase it, resulting in a more conservative upper bound of their out-degrees. The number of updates required for the last node being stable highly depends on the network topology. If λ𝜆\lambda is large, then most nodes have degree one or two, and 𝒮1subscript𝒮1\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{1} contains most nodes in 𝒩𝒩\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}. In this case, we can expect ∪α=1,⋯,s𝒮α=𝒩subscript𝛼1⋯𝑠subscript𝒮𝛼𝒩\cup_{\alpha=1,\cdots,s}\operatorname{\mathcal{S}}_{\alpha}=\operatorname{\mathcal{N}} with a small s𝑠s, so selecting a small m¯¯𝑚\overline{m} still provides a small h¯¯ℎ\overline{h} with fast convergence time. Our experience shows that selecting m¯¯𝑚\overline{m} around 101010 is sufficient to yield an optimal coloring for electrical networks. The number may increase for some large networks that involve thousands of nodes.

VI Simulations

Here, we validate the performance of the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm over the six bus test cases in [38], IEEE 14, 30, and 57 bus test cases. We first use Algorithms 2-3 to find an acyclic orientation of each test case, cf. Table I.

This results in orientations with diameter two for all test cases except the six bus test cases, with diameter three.

Figure 2 shows the convergence of Algorithm 1 for the various test cases. The stopping criteria is γi<10−4subscript𝛾𝑖superscript104\gamma_{i}<10^{-4} for all i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\operatorname{\mathcal{N}}. The horizontal axis in the plots is the global iteration number, not the iteration per bus (the number of iterations per bus is roughly the global iteration number divided by the diameter of the acyclic orientation).

Table II and Figure 2 show that the weighted selection of ρ𝜌\rho, discussed in Remark IV.5, leads to a much faster convergence than the uniform ρi​k=ρ0subscript𝜌𝑖𝑘subscript𝜌0\rho_{ik}=\rho_{0}, for all {i,k}∈ℰ𝑖𝑘ℰ\{i,k\}\in\operatorname{\mathcal{E}}. We have also simulated the case with unreliable communication, where every link has a 10%percent1010\% probability of packet drop if the previous communication was successful. Table II shows that the Algorithm 1 still converges, albeit requiring more iterations than the case with no packet drops. Figure 3 illustrates the transient behavior for the packet drop case.

Finally, we evaluate the impact of the acyclic orientation in the algorithm convergence in Figure 4. We simulate how Algorithm 1 converges for the IEEE 14 and 30 bus test cases with an arbitrarily chosen acyclic orientation instead of the one obtained from the execution of Algorithms 2-3. Compared with Figure 2(b)-(c), one can observe that the algorithm requires many more iterations to converge and that ‖r‖norm𝑟\|r\| increases dramatically at several iterations. These abrupt changes can also be explained as the result of several long paths in the digraph. In fact, recall that every node in a path makes one iteration before transferring its update to the following node. Starting with one of the terminal nodes in a long path, the update propagates through many nodes before reaching the other terminal node for its next update, at which point it may introduce a big change on its decision variables resulting in a dramatic change on ‖r‖norm𝑟\|r\|. Therefore, the selection of an acyclic orientation with small diameter has the added benefit, beyond reducing the average waiting time per iteration, of resulting in less abrupt changes in the algorithm execution.

VII Conclusions

We have designed the scheduled-asynchronous algorithm to solve SDP convexified OPF problems in a distributed way. Under the proposed strategy, every pair of nodes connected in the electrical network update their local variables in an alternating fashion and the ordering of node updates is encoded by an orientation of the network. We have established the algorithm convergence to the optimizer when the orientation is acyclic and shown how, when the network is bipartite, the strategy corresponds to the ADMM scheme and has therefore O​(1/n)𝑂1𝑛O(1/n) convergence rate. The convergence result does not require strong convexity of the cost function, which makes it especially suitable in OPF applications. To improve the algorithm convergence rate, we have introduced a distributed graph coloring algorithm that finds an acyclic orientation with small diameter for networks with geometric degree distribution. Future work will explore the characterization of the convergence rate for general network topologies, the optimal selection of the algorithm parameters, and the formal analysis of the algorithm robustness properties observed in simulation.

Appendix A Appendices

A-A Auxiliary Results for the Proof of Theorem IV.3

We gather here various auxiliary results used in the proof of Theorem IV.3. Our first result shows that two classes of convex optimization problems with separable cost functions have the same optimal solution.

Lemma A.1.

Let ϕ,φ:ℋn→ℝ:italic-ϕ𝜑→superscriptℋ𝑛ℝ\phi,\varphi:\mathcal{H}^{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} be convex and differentiable, and let 𝒳𝒳\operatorname{\mathcal{X}} be a convex set. Then

X⋆∈argminX∈𝒳⁡ϕ​(X)+φ​(X),superscript𝑋⋆subscriptargmin𝑋𝒳italic-ϕ𝑋𝜑𝑋\displaystyle X^{\star}\in\operatorname{argmin}_{X\in\operatorname{\mathcal{X}}}\phi(X)+\varphi(X), (A.35a)
⇔⇔\displaystyle\Leftrightarrow\; X⋆∈argminX∈𝒳⁡ϕ​(X)+⟨▽φ​(X⋆),X⟩.superscript𝑋⋆subscriptargmin𝑋𝒳italic-ϕ𝑋▽𝜑superscript𝑋⋆𝑋\displaystyle X^{\star}\in\operatorname{argmin}_{X\in\operatorname{\mathcal{X}}}\phi(X)+\langle\bigtriangledown\varphi(X^{\star}),X\rangle. (A.35b)
Proof.

The necessary and sufficient condition for X⋆superscript𝑋⋆X^{\star} being the optimal solution of optimization (A.35a) is that

⟨▽(ϕ​(X⋆)+φ​(X⋆)),X−X⋆⟩≥0,▽italic-ϕsuperscript𝑋⋆𝜑superscript𝑋⋆𝑋superscript𝑋⋆0\displaystyle\big{\langle}\bigtriangledown\big{(}\phi(X^{\star})+\varphi(X^{\star})\big{)},X-X^{\star}\big{\rangle}\geq 0,

for all X∈𝒳𝑋𝒳X\in\operatorname{\mathcal{X}}. We can rewrite the condition above as

⟨▽ϕ​(X⋆),X−X⋆⟩+⟨▽φ​(X⋆),X−X⋆⟩≥0,▽italic-ϕsuperscript𝑋⋆𝑋superscript𝑋⋆▽𝜑superscript𝑋⋆𝑋superscript𝑋⋆0\displaystyle\big{\langle}\bigtriangledown\phi(X^{\star}),X-X^{\star}\big{\rangle}+\big{\langle}\bigtriangledown\varphi(X^{\star}),X-X^{\star}\big{\rangle}\geq 0, (A.36)

for all X∈𝒳𝑋𝒳X\in\operatorname{\mathcal{X}}. Eq. (A.36) is also the optimality condition of optimization Eq. (A.35b), which completes the proof. ∎
